The Pros and Cons of Expressways



program as the construction of expressways, the likely result would be a
series of remedial measures on a piecemeal basis to relieve points of ex-
treme congestion—a street widening here, a grade separation there, etc.

In addition to these relatively small-scale improvements there would
probably also develop over a period of years a gradual series of changes in
the metropolitan area representing a multitude of individual adjustments
to the level of congestion. There would almost certainly be a speed-up in
the decentralization of downtown firms and activities and a continued
or accelerated, decline in the.central business district. Outlying shopping
centers would tend not only to serve the shopping needs of surrounding
areas but would more and more take on many of the functions which
previously were best handled by the central business district.

Workers would tend to adjust either their jobs or their homes so that
the two would be in closer proximity. It might be said, from a planning
point of view, that this is a desirable result and so it would be if it came
about through free choice. When, however, it is forced by congestion it
normally means that the worker, restricted in his choice of job or home
site, will end up with a less desirable job or home, or both. At the same
time employers will find that they are able to draw from a smaller and
smaller labor market.

With the Baltimore region tending to become a series of urbanized
sections rather than a unified city, many functions which can only be
supported on a metropolitan area basis will find survival difficult if not
impossible. The smaller specialized shops and services, the theater, con-
certs, museums and similar activities will occupy a smaller and smaller
place in the life of the community. People, finding it difficult to con-
gregate in a central place, will fairly quickly lose the habit of making an
effort to do so.

These gradual adjustments in land uses, in the relationship between

home and jobs, and in habits will tend, along with spot improvements in
street facilities, to place an upper level on congestion and to keep it from
getting completely out of hand. Another factor operating to the same end
will be that economic growth will proceed at a slower rate than antici-
pated. With a high level of congestion in the Baltimore metropolitan
area some firms that otherwise might move here from elsewhere will not
do so. Others now here may move entirely outside of the Baltimore area.
The anticipated increases in traffic described in Chapter IV of this report
are predicated on a reasonable rate of economic growth and assume that
congestion within the area will not be a serious deterrent to this growth.
If congestion is a deterrent then traffic will not increase to the extent
predicted.

If then we feel that the price which must be paid for a planned

expansion of our street and highway facilities (through expressways or .

otherwise) in order to meet anticipated traffic increases is too high we
probably face a future characterized by increased congestion, reduced
mobility, less freedom to select jobs or home sites, a speed-up in decen-
tralization, a greater dispersion of many functions throughout the metro-
politan area, a lower level of cultural activities and of specialized services
and businesses, and a reduced rate of economic growth.
